item.title: UFOs in fiction

UFOs in Fiction ðŸ”—

This article explores the prevalence of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) in various forms of fictional media, including books, radio, films, television, and video games. It notes that UFOs in fiction often serve as vehicles for alien invasions or encounters, sometimes drawing inspiration from real-world UFO reports.

Books ðŸ”—

This section lists books that feature UFOs or related concepts. A key point is the early use of the word “Starship” in Oahspe: A New Bible by John Ballou Newbrough (1882), predating its popularization in science fiction. The War of the Worlds by H.G. Wells (1898) is also mentioned, featuring Martian capsules launched towards Earth.

Radio ðŸ”—

This section highlights Orson Welles’ 1938 radio adaptation of The War of the Worlds, which famously caused widespread panic among listeners who believed the fictional alien invasion was real.

Television ðŸ”—

This section categorizes UFO-related television programs into three types: shows featuring real UFOs, hoax stories, and instances of misidentified terrestrial spacecraft.

Examples of shows depicting real UFOs include The Outer Limits, The Invaders, Dark Skies, Roswell, and The X-Files.

Hoax stories are found in shows like Batman, The Beverly Hillbillies, and Mission: Impossible.

Earth ships mistaken for UFOs appear in I Dream of Jeannie, Lost in Space, and Star Trek: The Original Series.
